M.G.L. c. 186.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord implicitly covenants that the tenant shall have the beneficial and peaceful use and enjoyment of the leased premises free from substantial interference by the landlord’s acts or omissions (the covenant of quiet enjoyment).

Card v. Davis, 276 Mass. 24 (1931).proposition: Card v. Davis, 276 Mass. 24 (1931) (discusses landlord obligations and tenants’ possession).
Card v. Davis, 276 Mass. 24 (1931).support_reasoning: The case concerns whether certain writings constituted an enforceable contract to purchase real estate or merely an option; it turns on contract formation, option renewal, and the absence of a binding promise to buy. The opinion does mention a tenant’s presence and an obligation by the seller to cause the tenant to vacate, but only as a condition within the option language, not as a discussion or holding about general landlord obligations or rules governing tenants’ possession. Accordingly, it does not meaningfully discuss or establish principles about landlord obligations and tenants’ possession.
Card v. Davis, 276 Mass. 24 (1931).relevant_excerpt: “The within option is hereby renewed for a period up to and including February 1, 1929, under the same terms and conditions as stated therein and on the further condition that said Margaret Kelley will cause the tenant Donald J. Ferguson to vacate the within premises on or before February 1, 1929. If tenant is out as stated, the said Earl A. Ryder will take conveyance of the property on February 1, 1929, provided title is satisfactory.”

North Atlantic Properties,.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns the appointment of a conservator for an elderly man under a Massachusetts statute and analyzes his mental capacity to manage property. It does not involve landlord–tenant law, leases, or any covenant of quiet enjoyment, express or implied, nor does it discuss that doctrine. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the recognition of a covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Hennessey v. North Atlantic Properties,.relevant_excerpt:
General Laws (Ter. Ed.) c. 201, § 16, as appearing in St. 1945, c. 728, § 2, provides as follows: “If a person by reason of advanced age or mental weakness is unable to properly care for his property, the probate court may…appoint a conservator to have charge and management of his property, subject to the direction of the court.”
…
“It cannot be said rightly that, in negotiating the loan in question from Miss Hubley when the bank was pressing him to make repairs, he was acting in an improvident manner or one significant of mental weakness.”

Saville v. Loma, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 672 (.relevant_excerpt: "After a jury in the Superior Court returned a verdict of guilty of conspiracy to commit armed robbery, the defendant filed this appeal. He also appeals from the denial of his motion for new trial, and the two matters have been consolidated. In his direct appeal, the defendant argues that he is entitled to a reversal of his conviction because of the bias displayed against him and his counsel during the trial by the trial judge and because of the denial of some of the defendant’s requested jury instructions."

DePasquale v. State St. Trust Co., 371 M.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns corporate political expenditures and First Amendment/equal protection challenges to Massachusetts campaign finance statute G.L. c. 55, § 8, in the context of a referendum on a graduated income tax. It does not address landlord-tenant law, premises liability, or any duties of landlords regarding premises. Therefore, citing this case for landlord duties regarding premises is inaccurate and unsupported by the opinion’s subject matter or holdings.
DePasquale v. State St. Trust Co., 371 M.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiffs’ first constitutional claim is that G. L. c. 55, § 8, violates their rights under the First Amendment to the United States Constitution. They argue that the section is invalid on its face, and that it is overbroad and void for vagueness. Alternatively they claim that, even if facially valid, the statute is unconstitutional as applied to them... Thus, we hold today that only when a general political issue materially affects a corporation’s business, property or assets may that corporation claim First Amendment protection for its speech...

Anderson v. Balducci, 390 Mass. 162 (198.support_reasoning: The case concerns public-sector labor law and the allocation of prosecutorial duties between police officers and town counsel, specifically whether that decision is a mandatory subject of collective bargaining. It does not involve a landlord-tenant relationship, conditions of leased premises, or any doctrine of landlord liability affecting tenants’ use and enjoyment. Therefore, citing Anderson v. Balducci for landlord liability for conditions affecting tenants’ use is inaccurate and unsupported by the opinion.
Anderson v. Balducci, 390 Mass. 162 (198.relevant_excerpt: "Thus, we hold that the decision to assign prosecutorial duties, subject only to the authority of the Attorney General and district attorney, is an exclusive managerial prerogative, and not a proper subject for collective bargaining."

Conway v. Flaherty, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 18.relevant_excerpt: We perceive no error in the judge’s rulings in the circumstances. Rice v. Wood, 366 Mass. 92 (1974).proposition: Rice v. Wood, 366 Mass. 92 (1974) (relief for tenants for landlord interference).
Rice v. Wood, 366 Mass. 92 (1974).support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal case about ineffective assistance of counsel and standards for evaluating adequacy of representation. It does not deal with landlord-tenant law, interference by landlords with tenants’ rights, or any form of tenant relief. Therefore, citing Rice v. Wood for the proposition ‘relief for tenants for landlord interference’ is inaccurate and unsupported by the case’s holding or reasoning.
Rice v. Wood, 366 Mass. 92 (1974).relevant_excerpt: “What is required in the actual process of decision of claims of ineffective assistance of counsel…is a discerning examination and appraisal of the specific circumstances of the given case to see whether there has been serious incompetency, inefficiency, or inattention of counsel… and, if that is found, then… whether it has likely deprived the defendant of an otherwise available, substantial ground of defence.” (366 Mass. at 96)
